column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.StanzaNER|value
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Relationships|Relationship|BT_webanno.custom.StanzaNER
#Text=Dos Cabezas is a Moche cultural site on Peru ’ s north coast that was the site of a major tomb looting event in the 1970s or 1980s and several recent looting incidents .

#Text=The site of Zona Arqueológica Cerro Dos Cabezas is located in the Jequetepeque Valley of Peru ’ s North Coast and consists of approximately one square kilometre of archaeological remains , including a 105-foot terraced pyramid .
#Text=The site was occupied from around AD 150 to 550 by the Moche culture .
#Text=It is believed that certain sectors of the site had already been looted by the 1970s , although that material from the looting did not hit the art market until the 1980s .
#Text=In the immediate aftermath of the looting of the spectacular Moche tombs at Sipán , it is likely that Dos Cabezas was looted again .
#Text=In 1994 an archaeological team lead by Christopher Donnan of UCLA began rescue excavations at Dos Cabezas .
#Text=Their primary goal was to explore and preserve tombs which had already been looted .
#Text=Donnan went on to find several unlooted Moche tombs containing gold and silver objects .
#Text=Donnan has stated that “ the only [ Moche ] tombs that are richer are those that were excavated at Sipán ” .
#Text=Looting remains a perennial problem at Dos Cabezas .
#Text=The core of the site is large and difficult to monitor effectively .
#Text=Even daytime looting could easily go unnoticed and some reports indicate that looting incidents have occurred there while archaeologists were working within the archaeological zone .
#Text=Around November of 2009 Dos Cabezas was hit by a new spree of looting incidents .

#Text=Archaeologists from Peru ’ s Departamento de Monumentos Arqueológicos determined that a previously unknown tomb was completely sacked and a large portion of the pyramid was damaged by the digging .
#Text=Sometime during the week of 5 February of 2011 , Dos Cabezas was looted once again .

#Text=The south-eastern side of the main pyramid at the site was damaged by around 20 different looters ’ pits and an analysis of the spoil indicated that the looters had encountered another elite tomb .
#Text=The looters were rumoured to be locals who were employed by known antiquities traffickers .

#Text=The deputy mayor of the municipality , Fernando Isla Merino , criticised the looting and indicated that local government ’ s hands were tied : they were unable to protect the monument and were seeking to coordinate efforts with governmental authorities .
#Text=Experts from the Dirección Regional de Cultura located twenty three recent looters ’ holes at the site in late March 2011 .
#Text=In August 2011 archaeologist Steve Bourget donated funds for the salaries of two round-the-clock guards to monitor site in an effort to prevent further looting .
#Text=Objects thought to be from the site of Dos Cabezas appear in museum and private collections around the world and have been the subject of high profile trafficking seizures .
#Text=On 5 August 2009 , US Immigration and Customs Enforcement seized two Moche ceramic vessels that had landed at JFK Airport , New York , aboard a Swiss Air flight .
#Text=The pieces are thought to have come from either Dos Cabezas or the nearby site of La Mina .
#Text=They were accompanied by forged invoices that indicated the vessels had been purchased in the 1960s in Germany .
#Text=The importer , German collector Anton Roeckl , was alleged to have fabricated the invoices .
#Text=Roeckl returned the pieces to Peru on 2 November 2010 as part of a settlement to avoid charges .
